habitat_description: During the breeding season, the least tern forms colonies along coasts or rivers, on sand, or dried mudflats that are bare or sparsely vegetated.  Sand or shell beaches are preferred, but nests will also occasionally be built amongst stone. Nests are generally placed above the high-tide level, or on riverine sandbars where vegetation is limited due to seasonal flooding. Nesting colonies are often near lagoons, estuaries, rivers or coasts (Thompson et al. 1997). Due to habitat fragmentation and loss to human use, breeding habitat has been expanded from natural areas to include agricultural fields, parking lots, bare land near airports, dredge spoil, and flat, graveled rooftops (Thompson et al. 1997). C. Maynard, 23feb10.
